dialogueHeader.title: RIOT IN OXFORD
dialogueHeader.author: unknown
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: THE SEVERAL DEPOSITIONS CONCERNING THE LATE RIOT IN OXFORD. LONDON: PRINTED FOR JOHN MORPHEW, NEAR STATIONER'S-HALL. 1716. PP. 3.1 - 38.19

dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF RICHARD BOXLEY OF OXFORD, BARBER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE ONE AND THIRTIETH DAY OF OCTOBER, ANNO DOM. 1716. BEFORE RICHARD WISE, ESQ; MAYOR, AND SIR DANIEL WEBB, KNT. TWO OF HIS MAJESTY'S JUSTICES OF THE PEACE FOR THE SAID CITY .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: This Informant saith, That last Night he was at a Neighbour's House in the Northgate-street in Oxford aforesaid, and hearing a great Noise of Breaking of Windows, he went out; and when he came into the Street he saw a great many Soldiers throwing Stones at the Windows of Mr. Hurst the Ironmonger, being encouraged by an Officer of the Regiment, whose Name this Informant knoweth not; and after some time, a Gentleman, whom this Informant believes was the Major, said to them,
dialogueText.dialogue: Come in, Boys, and drink, and then go out and at it again ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and accordingly they did go in with him, and when they came out again, the Major, pointing to Mr. Hurst's House, said to the Soldiers,
dialogueText.dialogue: Down with that House, and I will see it out ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
upon which they throw'd more Stones at Mr. Hurst's Windows, and then went up the Street, and afterwards into the High-Street, breaking Windows all the way they went,
and afterwards came back to the Star for fresh Orders, as they pretended; and after they had stay'd there some little time, they went down the Northgate-street , and thro' the North-gate , breaking the Windows all the way they went, and beating some People.

Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , Richard Boxley .
Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF THOMAS COLLER OF OXFORD, CORDWAINER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That he was last Night standing by the Bonfire against the Star-Inn in this City, and there saw a great many Soldiers breaking Mr. Hurst's Windows, and while they were about it, one of the Lieutenants, whose Name this Informant believes is Hamilton , came out and lighted his Pipe at the Bonfire, and all the while looking upon them; and when he had lighted his Pipe, he walked over into the Lane next Mr. Hurst's , and the Soldiers followed him; but what he said to them this Informant knows not; but said, That the Soldiers went immediately to gathering up of Stones, and then went up the Street, and down the High-Street, all the way breaking of Windows; And when they came near
Sir Daniel Webb's House, Sir Daniel overtook them, and ask'd them what they meant by making such a Disturbance? Whereupon they immediately fell a swearing and cursing, and several of them stuck him with their Sticks; and one Fosty Magee , a Corporal in the Colonel's Company (as this Informant is since told he is) drew his Sword, and held it against Sir Daniel : Whereupon this Informant told him Sir Daniel was a Justice of the Peace, and one of the Magistrates of the City: Upon which the said Magee curs'd Sir Daniel , and said, He did not care what he was ; further said, He was a Rogue and a Rascal . After which, they went over to Mr. Mayor's, and broke his Windows; and when Mr. Mayor came out to demand the Reason, several of them, and particularly the said Magee , came up to Mr. Mayor with their drawn Swords; and further saith, That Mr. Mayor went with his Mace, and accompany'd Sir Daniel Webb to the Major at the Star-Inn , to complain of the Disorders by the Soldiers, and to desire his Assistance; and as they came away from him this Informant heard the Major say,
dialogueText.dialogue: Go to the Devil like a Parcel of Jacobites, or I will make you go .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Capt. & Jur. Die & Anno supr. coram Nobis , Thomas Coller . Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF JOHN HURST, JUN. OF OXFORD, IRON-MONGER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID, BEFORE THE REV. JOHN BARON, D.D. &C. VICE-CHANCELLOR OF THE UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD, AND OTHER THE JUSTICES AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: This Informant saith, That when they were lighting the Bonfire, last Night, against the Star-Inn , he, this Informant, shut up his Father's Shop-Windows (the House being over against the Star ) and went in to his Work; and after a very little time, this Informant's Sister said, She heard the Glass-Windows rattle , which this Informant could not at first believe; but soon after this Informant heard it himself, and then went out to see who it was that broke the Windows; and when he came out, he saw the Major of the Regiment take up a Stone, and brake the Windows with it; upon which this Informant said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Sir, I will take a Note of your Name ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: whereupon the Major drew his Sword, and ran after this Informant, and said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Damn you, will you take Notice of Names ?
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
But this Informant ran into his Father's House, and lock'd the Door before the Major could overtake him; but they still continu'd to break the Windows, which, after some time, provok'd this Informant to go out again, and then he saw the Major throw a Fire-Stick from the Bonfire at his Father's Windows; and did at the
same time likewise see the Tapster at the Star-Inn , and one Edward West , the under-Tapster, throw Firesticks at, and broke the said Windows; and further saith, they broke a great deal of China-Ware , and that one of the Firesticks hung in the Window-Curtain, and that there was no Person in the House besides this Informant's Mother, his two Sisters, and himself, that Night; and that none of them were upon the Leads, or in the Spout, that Night.

Capt. & Jur. Die & Anno supr. cora. nob. John Hurst , jun.
Jo. Baron, Vice Can. Rich. Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF WILLIAM CLARK OF OXFORD, INN-HOLDER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE THIRTY FIRST DAY OF OCTOBER, ANNOQ; DOM. 1716. BEFORE THE REV. JOHN BARON, D.D. AND VICE-CHANCELLOR OF THE UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD, RICHARD WISE, ESQ; MAYOR OF THE CITY OF OXFORD, WILLIAM WRIGHT, ESQ; RECORDER OF THE SAME CITY, SIR DANIEL WEBB, KNT. AND JAMES PINNEL, ALDERMAN, FIVE OF HIS MAJESTY'S JUSTICES OF THE PEACE FOR THE SAID CITY .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That last Night when the Bonefire was burning, against the Star-Inn , the Major of the Regiment came out of the said Inn, with his
Sword drawn, and seeing the Wife of Mr. Hurst , the Iron-monger, at her Chamber-Window, he said to her,
dialogueText.dialogue: God Damn you for a Bitch, if you don't light up Candles, and let them remain, I will pull your House down, and set it on Fire ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and then took a Stone, and broke the Windows; and after that, one Thomas Walker , a Tapster, at the said Star-Inn , threw a Firestick at the said Window: And further saith, That after the Soldiers had broke the Windows, about the Town, the Major came by this Informant's House, and said,
dialogueText.dialogue: God Damn these Jacobite-Rascals SOURCE TEXT: NO ITALICS FOR Jacobite , we have made them suffer for it now .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Capt. & Jur. Die & Anno. supr. coram nobis . William Clark . John Baron, Vice-Can. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF FRANCIS BERRY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD, COOK, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That while the Bonefire was burning, last Night, before the Star-Inn , the Major of the Regiment, and Mr. Baker of Wadham-College , were standing at the Gate of the said Inn, and this Informant saw Mr. Baker call several of the Soldiers to him, and clap'd them upon the Back; and as soon as they went
from him, they fell to breaking Mr. Hurst's Windows, the Major and Mr. Baker still standing at the Gate, and looking upon them: And this Informant likewise saw three Soldiers break Mr. Cole's , the Glazier's, Windows, and said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Damn him, we will break his Windows, because he is a Glazier, and can mend them himself .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
Capt. & Jur. Die & Anno. Supr. Coram Nobis , Francis Berry .
John Baron, Vice-Can. Rich. Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF THOMAS VICARIS OF OXFORD, SALTER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: This Informant saith, That Yesterday the Major of the Regiment and one of the Captains, accidentally met near this Informant's Brother's House, he this Informant then standing at the Door, and the Captain ask'd the Major, Where he was going so early with his Boots on ? the Major said, He was willing to be in a readiness, and that he would break every Window that Night, by God : upon which, the Captain ask'd, Why ? and he said, because never a Bell had stir'd that Day ; and then they parted. And further saith, That about an Hour after, the Major and another Officer came down the Street together, and as they pass'd by, the Major said,
dialogueText.dialogue: The City is maintain'd by the University, and 'tis their Faults the Bells did not Ring, and by God I will break every College-Window this Night .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , Thomas Vicaris. John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF JOHN GILLETT OF OXFORD, LABOURER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That last Night he was at the Cross-Inn , and Mrs. Gyles
who kept the House, hearing a Noise in the Street of breaking Windows, she went to the Gate with a Candle in her Hand, and said to the Soldiers,
dialogueText.dialogue: Pray, Gentlemen, don't break my Windows: Good Gentlemen, don't break my Windows .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Upon which, one Charter , a Corporal in the Major's Company, said,
dialogueText.dialogue: God damn you for an old Bitch ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and struck the Candle out of her Hand with a great Stick, and then struck her upon the left Arm in such a violent manner, that he almost beat her down.
Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , John Gillett O his Mark . John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise Mayor , Daniel Webb, William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF EDWARD COSENS OF OXFORD, CHANDLER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That as he was standing at his Mother's Door last Night between Eight and Nine of the Clock,
he saw a great Number of Soldiers come down the Street, and breaking of Windows all the way they came; and when they came to this Informant, a Corporal, who led them up, said to the rest of them,
dialogueText.dialogue: Gentlemen, break these Windows :
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Upon which this Informant ask'd,
dialogueText.dialogue: Why will you break the Windows ?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Whereupon the Corporal ask'd this Informant who he was? and he told him, He was Master of the House : Upon which he said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Then I will knock you down ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: which he accordingly did with a Stick he brought with him; and after this Informant had got up again, he talk'd with them, and told them the great Hardship it was for People to have their Windows broke in such manner, and such like Talk; whereupon they went away, having only one Stone thrown at his Windows; and further saith, That as he was getting up, after he was knock'd down, a Soldier struck at him with a drawn Sword, but did not hit him.

Capt. & Jur. Die & Anno supr. coram Nobis . Edw. Cosens .
Jo. Baron. Vice-Can. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF JOHN LUCAS OF OXFORD, CUTLER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That he was coming out of the Sun-Inn and going home, last Tuesday , just as Mr. Mayor came up Town to disperse the Soldiers that were
breaking of Windows, but was stop'd by a Constable, who charg'd this Informant to go along with and assist Mr. Mayor, which this Informant did accordingly: And when Mr. Mayor came back to his own Door, this Informant saw some Soldiers with Muskets, and some body said
dialogueText.dialogue: Pho, Pho .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Upon which, one of the Soldiers said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Damn you, what you mean by Pho, Pho ?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and then presented their Muskets towards the Place where Mr. Mayor was; and one of the Soldiers said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Damn you, Fire :
dialogueText.nonSpeech: And immediately three or four of them did Fire: And this Informant hath since heard, that one of them shot the Mace-bearer thro' his Hat with a Bullet, as it was upon his Head: And further saith, That after they had fired, as aforesaid, one of them said,
dialogueText.dialogue: Damn you, if that will not do, we will put in a Brace of Bullets .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , John Lucas. John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb, Henry White.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF JOHN PAVIER OF OXFORD, TAYLOR, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That last Tuesday Night he saw a great Number of Soldiers, and one Edward West an Hostler at the
Star-Inn threw Stones and Fire-sticks at Mr. Hurst's Windows, the Major of the Regiment all the while looking on; and this Informant heard the Major say to the Soldiers,
dialogueText.dialogue: God damn you, Boys, pull down the House, I will see it out ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and saith, That one of the Soldier's Names is John Stockley : And further saith, That about nine of the Clock the same Night, a Corporal of the Major's Company, who lodgeth at one Wooten's a Hempdresser, knock'd this Informant down without any provocation, or without saying any thing to him.

Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , John Pavier.
John Baron. Vice-Canc. Robert FOR Richard? Wise, Mayor , Daniel Webb, Henry White.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF JOHN IVES OF OXFORD, YEOMAN, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That this Morning he this Informant, and Mr. Green the Glazier, and one Mrs. Blower , had some talk in relation to the Windows which were broke by the Soldiers last Tuesday Night, and while they were thus talking, the Major of the Regiment crossed the Street to meet Mr. Hawkins the Adjutant, and just as they came to the Door where they were, he nodded his Head
towards Mr. Hurst's House, and said,
dialogueText.dialogue: God damn you, I wish they had pull'd the House down .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , John Ives.
John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise, Mayor , Daniel Webb, Henry White.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF HENRY SILVESTER AND RICHARD COLTON, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID, BEFORE THE JUSTICES AFORESAID, AND SIR DANIEL WEBB, KT .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: These Informants say, that they were standing at a Door last Tuesday-Morning , next to Sir Daniel Webb's , when he and the Major of the Regiment were talking together, and heard the Major ask Sir Daniel, why the Bells did not ring ? but they could not hear what Answer Sir Daniel made him; but heard the Major say further,
dialogueText.dialogue: What! you are govern'd by the Colleges, and do what they would have you; they are a Parcel of disaffected Rogues, and I will break their Windows for it at Night .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , Henry Silvester. Richard Colton. John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF NATHAN STOKE, OF BRAZEN-NOSE-COLLEGE, IN THE UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD, BATCHELOR OF ARTS, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, that last Tuesday-Morning he, this Informant, and one Mr. Thomas Harris , of the same College with
this Informant, were at Hamilton's Coffee-House in Oxford , when the Major of the Regiment came in Swearing and Cursing, and said,
dialogueText.dialogue: not a Bell stir'd this Morning ;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: whereupon this Informant asked the said Mr. Harris what Day it was? but the Major hearing the Question, answer'd, it was the Prince's Birth-Day , and said, it was the Disaffection of the Governours, who were a Pack of Villains, which occasion'd their not Ringing ; then this Informant said,

and he said No, that was a good Honest College, and that the Constitution-Club knew it was the Prince's Birth-Day ; and so continu'd Swearing, that he would send Soldiers at Night to break the Windows of the Colleges; and repeated the same very often, and was in a very great Passion.

Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , Nathan Stoke .
John Baron, Vice-Can. Richard Wise, Mayor . Daniel Webb. William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF WILLIAM SMITH, OF OXFORD, YEOMAN, TAKEN UPON OATH THE DAY AND YEAR AFORESAID .
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
This Informant saith, That last Tuesday Night he was standing by the Bonfire at the Star , and saw the Soldiers break Mr. Hurst's Windows all to Pieces; and when they had so done, they began to throw Stones at other People's Windows, and particularly Mr. Cooper's the Barber; and some one that stood by said, It was pity to break them, for he was a poor Man ; whereupon the Major ask'd what he was? and Mr. Wisdome the Cutler
answer'd,
dialogueText.dialogue: He is not right ,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: or
dialogueText.dialogue: He is not a Whig ,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: but this Informant is not sure which he said: And then a Nobleman (who this Informant believes was the Marquis of Hartington ) desired the Major to call the Soldiers away, otherwise it would make a great Disturbance in the Town; upon which the Major call'd them to him, and bid them come in and Drink; and when they came into the Back-side of the Star-Inn , several Persons said to them,
dialogueText.dialogue: Come in and drink the King's Health Boys, and at it again ,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and after that they broke more Windows in several parts of the Town.

Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , William Smith.
John Baron, Vice-Canc. Richard Wise, Daniel Webb, William Wright.
dialogueText.head: THE INFORMATION OF RICHARD BROWN, OF OXFORD, BARBER, AND WILLIAM PARKER, OF THE SAME, INN-HOLDER, TAKEN UPON OATH THE 3D DAY OF NOVEMBER, ANNO DOM. 1716. BEFORE RICHARD WISE, ESQ; MAYOR, AND SIR DANIEL WEBB, KT. TWO OF HIS MAJESTY'S JUSTICES OF THE PEACE FOR THE SAID CITY .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: These Informants say, that as soon as the Bonfire was lighted against the Star-Inn , last Tuesday Night, the Major of the Regiment came out of the said Inn, and said to the Soldiers that were in the Street,
dialogueText.dialogue: Break not One but All: Pull down the House, and I will answer it :
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and thereupon they immediately began breaking Mr. Hurst's Windows.
Capt. & Jur. die & Anno supr. coram nobis , Richard Brown, William Baker. Richard Wise, Mayor , Daniel Webb.
